title: I'm 15 years old, I want to become a journalist. What should I do? - Quora

response.answer_text: Write. Write 500 words every day. Write about what happened in school. Write what happened in the world — summarize the event and possibly comment on it but make it clear where the boundary is.Don’t major in journalism. Take courses in journalism for some of your electives, but major in either political science or history, or possibly general science if you are a techy. You can’t write effectively about what you don’t understand.Write. Get on Reddit. Find a dozen topics that interest you. Comment knowledgeably about them. This may mean you spend 2 hours doing internet reading to write a 3 line reply.Read voraciously.Keep a journal. Here is where you can write about all the joys and troubles of being 15Write a blog. Initially write once a week. Try for a theme. Use a nomme de plume, so that your kid writings of today don’t come back to haunt you in 15 years. Your journal may be a source of ideas for this.Read about propaganda. Read about spin. Read about how to be objective.Let that affect your writing. Try always for openness, but not to the exclusion of rationality.Learn statistics. Learn what those phrases mean. Learn how to analyze statistical lies.Write about statistical deception.Learn about logical fallacies, and cognitive biases.Write about fallacies and biases.Learn to look for patterns.Write about patterns in your life, and the world you see.(You probably see a pattern forming here.) 15. If you have a friend, teacher, mentor who you trust with your soul, let them edit your writing. This hurts. Resolve to be silent about the criticism. Accept it, let it sit for 24 hours, then rewrite. 16. Look at what you wrote a year ago. Laugh. But you will laugh again a year from now. It takes a million or so words to learn how to write. At 500 a day, it will take 2000 days — about 6 years.

Do you want to be one of the journalists at a major publications (WSJ, NY Times, Financial Times) or do you just want to investigate news, write about it and get the information out there? If its the former, then what I would suggest is getting into the absolute best journalism school you can (or as an English major at a top school like Harvard, Yale, Stanford, etc if they don’t offer journalism). Here is more information on that: How can I get into an Ivy League college? During school make sure to get internships and be very active in the college newspaper. This will be important when you’re applying for jobs and need copies of work you’ve produced or need to validate your time at an internship. Also look at Linkedin at companies where you’d like to work and see how they achieved it. For example, if you wanted to write about Venture Capital for the WSJ here is a person who is currently doing that, Patience Haggin. Learn from their example, but know that today is different and it might take a different path. Now even if your goal is to just investigate and be a journalist, like a rogue journalist, the best advice is to do the same thing as if you wanted to work for WSJ as an on staff journalist. The knowledge you’d learn in those programs are worth their weight in gold (more so the connections, but knowledge too). Or, you can learn how to investigate news topics (here are a couple Quora questions which can help): What makes a good and valuable news story? How do I write a good crime investigation story? And there are tons of resources out there. Maybe speaking with current journalists about how they go about it. Or taking courses, or any way to learn. Then find the news. If you hit a huge story (like if you were the first person to report on Zenefits’ problems) you now have some credibility to build off of. Every story you come up with, submit to the top publications in that realm (think Thought Catalog, BuzzFeed, Business Insider, Forbes, Fortune) and while getting your name out there you might also get paid. Also I would suggest being extremely active in Quora. It can help you build your credibility and even give you the place where you can share your findings. Hope this helps! I wish I would’ve had Quora as a 15 year old.
